children.subject: Got it. So in exchange for ds100, which 16x class would you recommend? Would 186 fall in line w this?

If you want to open up SWE broadly as an option, 161, 162 are probably the most generally applicable, from what people I know who are in industry say. 168 and 186 are just a little more specific but they are also widely applicable as they grant a good understanding of database systems and networks/internet, which you are likely to come across at any SWE job--neither of these are bad to take if you want to go beyond 161, 162. The others like 160, 169 are generally considered more optional; and because they are typically hard to get into, I wouldn't recommend them. There is a smaller chance you'd need knowledge from 164 wherever you go. You can also consult the Piazza posts about these classes and the HKN course guide as they are very helpful for planning which course to take and my advice largely stems from these sources.

Keep in mind students generally say 162 is a heavy workload and 161, 168, 186 (while it depends on the student and they aren't equal in workload) have generally medium workloads. The difficulty may influence your decision. Hope it helps.

I would just add that if you are going to be taking 189 at some point, consider doing 127 or 126 first as this has been recommended many times by profs. like Sahai, though it is still very worth it to take them even afterward. If you do take 189, there's not as much reason to take Data 100 since it seems like after 189 you mainly just learn common data science tools like pandas, etc. in Data 100. Of all your classes that you could self-teach I'd say that one would be the most feasible to drop. As far as opening up many options for industry, if you take 189, 123, 126, 127, with the classes you are taking now, you would have a really good foundation for ML/signals/theory etc., but you will have only taken 162 (possibly 161) as your SWE-focused courses. You may want to consider taking one or two more 16X classes if you really want to open up the SWE option as well, as not doing so might leave you with a lot of mathematical experience but little programming experience. It may actually be hard to "self-teach" the 16X classes as generally students gain a lot from the projects and coding experience, and it's hard to get that experience if you don't have the framework and incentive of a class to force you to do large projects. But people typically find out eventually that they want to do either SWE or ML or EE etc. so you may end up refining your coursework, it may just be too early to tell.

Offering a different perspective, you may want to consider "specializing" in one subject. For example, after taking CS 189 you could take CS 188 (Intro to AI), CS 182 (Neural Nets), CS 285 (Deep Reinforcement Learning), or CS 280 (Computer Vision), which all tie specifically into AI/ML. Another perspective is exploring algorithms with CS 271 (Randomized Algorithms) or CS 270 (if it's offered again). Or if you are interested in controls, taking EE 106A and EE 106B (Robotics).

While you might miss out on the SWE-focused courses as Anon pointed out above, I think there is value in being able to take a few grad classes before graduating, or exploring domain-specific classes (something that's less of a toolkit class and more of a deeper dive into one subject).

history.content:
That's actually a pretty solid list. Everything is incorporating ML, so while 189 might be overkill in terms of amount of content, you wont get enough background in any other class to consider yourself on top of ML. Part of the core of all mathy CS is 126 and 127. This includes ML, robotics, signals and systems, and more, as everything is probabilistic, and with the combination of many variables and error in all values, you need linear algebra and optimization. 123 is called by the professor the "swiss army knife" of EECS. I haven't actually taken that one, but definitely good for anything EE, and while we don't do signal/system shit much in CS ugrad, I could see it being used in the field or grad school. 

162 is the essential systems course. 170 is essential for CS (and even some EE). 120 is essential for signals and systems stuff, to include robotics. I will say 100 isn't that important if you've taken the other stuff. I took 100 after 189 and I knew everything but how to use Pandas and Seaborn (python libraries for data manipulation (similar to SQL) and graphing). 186 is actually really important for any kind of stuff that requires a ton of data like ML as you need a way to actually work with the data. I'd say 161 is also really important for anyone programming products or systems, but as a transfer student trying to prioritize, 161 and 186 wouldn't be the highest for me compared to the others you listed.

I actually would disagree with the advice below to specialize unless you know what you want, especially when it comes to ML. You could do data science easily out of college with 189, but real specialized jobs often require more education; that's why classes like computer vision and NLP are grad classes at the moment. In general, I wouldn't recommend a grad class as a transfer student just because of time. If you wanna take them, go to grad school, where you have to specialize anyways. The exception to this would be taking at least one looks good on grad apps.

I will also disagree with the idea that 106a teaches controls at all. They do some, but they don't teach you how to use them effectively. 128 is really needed for that, but that is much more specialized. 106a is also fun though. 106b is effectively a grad survey of robotics for ugrads, so if you're planning for grad school and 100% certain about robotics, could be useful, but if not 100% sure I wouldn't recommend

TL;DR: 

Courses to be able to go whatever route you want (minus circuits; take 105 then): 126 (core prob), 127 (core linear algebra/Opt), 189 (ML), 120 (core signals/systems), 123 (Core signal processing), 170 (core theory), 162 (core computer systems)

Courses that are good but not top priority: 161, 186

Courses that expand opportunities that I like, but see if you're interested first: 106a, 128, 168

Take whatever else you want based on your interests

In general, use ugrad to get a broad base and figure out what you like, and use grad school for specialized stuff

children.subject: Personally I think 128 is better as a core course than 123, but other than that it's a solid list. 128 has some of the same filtering / signal processing stuff as 123 (laplace transforms are basically the same as fourier transforms), but I think you get a better sense of how to model systems mathematically that's missing from most other courses in that list.

history.content:
I asked one of the professors here about what courses to take, and he said 189, 126, 127, and 123 will give people the most versatile toolkit available after graduation. This semester I've been taking my first upper divs (currently in 120, 149, 170), and next sem I'll take 162, 123, and 189, and I might P/NP one of them cause I know it's going to be a tough workload.

I'm a transfer and can take a 5th semester, and was wondering if the addition of 126/127 (might throw data100 or 186 in there) would really be that useful. I want to have my options open after I graduate and work in any sector I'm interested in. I figured if I really want to be pure SWE I can pick up 186/161 knowledge on my own, but what are your thoughts on this track?
history.subject: Asked a prof about what courses to take, this is what he told me
